text: today on x cast the US ambassador to
Libya Christopher Stevens along with
three of his staff members were killed
Tuesday in what may have been a
pre-planned attack on the American
consulate in Benghazi since our founding
the United States has been a nation that
respects all faiths we reject all
efforts to denigrate the religious
beliefs of others but there is
absolutely no justification to this type
of senseless violence deputy foreign
editor Michael slack Minh spoke with
diplomatic correspondent Steven Lee
Myers about the early fallout Stephen
what's been the response so far in
Washington well as you would expect
there's a great outpouring of grief and
condolences the president has already
spoken from the Rose Garden Secretary of
State Clinton spoke in the treaty room
at the State Department President Obama
is on his way over there now
and is going to meet privately with the
workforce there to express his
condolences and and to thank them for
what is often as we've seen dangerous
work that diplomats do around the world
Stephen this is said to be a response to
a video that had gone out that many
Muslims felt insulted the Prophet
Muhammad that wasn't a surprise libya
posts the revolution has also been very
unstable is there thinking that perhaps
there was a security lapse there and
that more could have been done to
protect this to prevent this from
happening
well obviously after an incident like
this there's going to be a thorough
investigation by the diplomatic team
diplomatic security team at the State
Department to figure out what exactly
went wrong as I understand it not having
been to this particular building in
Benghazi that it wasn't a heavily
fortified compound the way many of our
embassies are and other places whether
or not that made it more vulnerable to
attack it's hard to say I think the real
question is this obscure video that
frankly no one here had ever heard of
until these protests began I think the
question is what incited such a
passionate angry response I mean it's a
very volatile time
in the region generally and in Libya in
particular there's competing forces now
vying for power and influence in a
transitional period all of that raises
the question I think again as to what
kind of security measures were put in
place since as you said it is a volatile
region at this time the United States
was very instrumental in helping bring
about the fall of Colonel Qaddafi and
the rise of this this new democratic
transition that they're attempting in
Libya does that perhaps add to the sense
of frustration and violation and
victimization and does it cause any kind
of rethinking of the policy towards
Libya well I think one of the things
that in fact ambassador Stevens talked
about a lot was the reception that he
received even when the conflict was
still underway remember he was the
representative to the Libyan rebels even
when Qaddafi was still in power and he
went to into Benghazi a year ago April
and talked about seeing the American
British French flags flying in the
square they renamed Freedom Plaza the
reception of many Libyans has been quite
welcoming and you know they appreciate
the support that the United States and
the other NATO nations gave to help
overthrow Qaddafi a Secretary Clinton in
her statement today said that this was
attacked by a small an attack by a small
group of savage thugs this is an attack
that should shock the conscience of
people of all faiths around the world we
condemn in the strongest terms this
senseless act of violence and we send
our prayers to the families friends and
colleagues of those we've lost
Stephen ambassador the ambassador was
known to be somewhat optimistic about
the future he felt that forces of change
had been unleashed and there was no
going back isn't that right he was I
mean I fact generally most of the
diplomats most ambassadors are fairly
optimistic about their countries and for
the most part and you know Libya has
gone through a tremendous transition
it's it's a difficult one it's a painful
one there's a lot of concern about
security there I heard today that in
recent months there have been
a string of attacks assassinations in
Benghazi suggesting a kind of if not
lawlessness at least a lot of turmoil
underway as the country you know strives
to two old elections and and become a
functioning democracy and with this
tragedy occurring right in the middle of
the political season here in the United
States it's injected foreign policy into
the campaign in a way we haven't seen
thus far
White House correspondent Peter Baker
reports the attacks in Benghazi and
protests in Cairo completely upended the
presidential campaign here in the United

criticizing the Obama administration for

Governor Romney made a hastily arranged

instead of condemning their actions it's

expressed outrage over the attacks
sympathy for the families of those who

by saying he rejects denigrating other

this is a rare instance where a foreign

obviously its confronts President Obama

American diplomats would be measured by
